video.title: Google Like a Pro – All Advanced Search Operators Tutorial [2023 Tips]
video.description:
Learn how to become more effective at searching the web!

In this video, student Seth Goldin discusses how Google works, how to ask the right questions and identify the best results, and using built-in search operators to power up your search!

🔗 Read more like this from Seth: https://goldin.io/blog

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (00:00) Intro
⌨️ (03:14) How Does Google Work
⌨️ (09:40) Asking the Right Questions
⌨️ (14:41) Identifying the Right Answers
⌨️ (23:40) What Are Search Operators?
🔍 (24:43) Matching Operators
🔍 (28:23) Date Operators
🔍 (29:58) Source Operators
🔍 (33:29) Boolean Operators
🔍 (34:03) In-(URL/Title/Text/Anchor) Operators
🔍 (37:02) Utility Operators
⌨️ (41:05) Using and Combining Search Operators
⌨️ (44:02) Google Lens and Image Search
⌨️ (46:29) Specialized Search Engines
⌨️ (51:21) Keyboard Shortcuts
⌨️ (52:38) Wrapping Everything Up

Disclaimer: This course is not affiliated with Google.

"Music: 8 Bit Win By HeatleyBros - 
https://youtu.be/vX1xq4Ud2z8"

🎉 Thanks to our Champion and Sponsor supporters:
👾 Nattira Maneerat
👾 Heather Wcislo
👾 Serhiy Kalinets
👾 Erdeniz Unvan
👾 Justin Hual
👾 Agustín Kussrow
👾 Otis Morgan

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: compangit
topLevelComment.text: Comments for myself: You can use * if you can't remember a word and google will read it as a "wildcard" word. word1 AROUND(X) word2 will search for results with around X amount of words in between word1 and word2. You can use before:yyyy-mm-dd or after to indicate a specific date. If you want a start and end date, you can use date1...date2 as the range operator. site:siteName to return results only from siteName. filetype:fileType to return results with fileType extension, e.g. filetype:pdf. loc:location. blogurl to return a blog from the url. cache:siteUrl returns backedup saved version of a site.

topLevelComment.author: telumire
topLevelComment.text:
For the lazy:


;Search keywords

Matching operator

* exact: `" "`
* exclusion: `-`
* wildcard: `*`
* around (X is the range of words in which the following term need to be around the preceding term): `AROUND(X)` 

Date operator

* `before:`
* `after:`
* `...` range operator (also work outside of dates):  2018..2022

Source operator

* `site/search:` (also works with top lovel domain, example : `site:.edu` )
* `ext/filetype:` doesnt work with mp3, use the inurl operator instead
* `source:`
* `loc/location:`
* `blogurl:`
* `cache:` open the cached url

Boolean operators

* `AND &&`
* `OR  |`

In operators

* `inurl/allinurl:`
* `intitle/allintitle:`
* `intext/allintext:`
* `inanchor/allinanchor:`

Utility operators

* `define:`
* `related:`
* `ip adress`
* `x in y`
* `$` example: `$300 android`, `keyboard $10...$50`
* `@` search media account
* `weather:`
* `map:`
* `movie:`
* `stocks:`
* `timer , x minutes timer`
* `stopwatch`
* `roll a die, flip a coin`
* `tip calculator`

replies.author: Andre du Plessis
replies.text: @Ou8y2k2 I would be highly surprised if there aren't AIs that has scraped every single bit of every byte there is in our solarsystem. Giving access to that level of information to the public will never happen. Which is completely logical. And MS's move to integrate OpenAI's features into Bing is another logical step. As are the moves Google will be making, agreed. The thing is this will be regulated, guaranteed. There is no other way to mitigate the risks. The prickly pear getting juggled by state-level orgs, to find a suitable "control-and-release" mechanism will be tossed around for a while yet, before some form of safe and sane unleashing to the information already available will be released into the wild. Imagine the chaos if it does not get regulated.

replies.author: Ou8y2k2
replies.text:
@Andre du Plessis While ChatGPT's knowlege base does end in late 2021, other AI tools do not end there. Google is bringing in Page and Brin to tackle the OpenAI problem because they see what's happening _right now._ Microsoft is looking to integrate ChatGPT into Bing which is more up to date than late 2021, and there's no law that prevents an AI tool from scraping the invisible web (which is composed of the deep and dark webs). ;-)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=awdEncOc6H0

Just a quick note that Google is partially wrong here in its search result – I do not own freeCodeCamp any more than you do. When we applied for tax-exempt status many years ago, I donated all my shares to freeCodeCamp, which is now a 501(c)(3) public charity. topLevelComment.author: David
topLevelComment.text: 10:50 — 214 million results? Well guess what. You can’t click past page 5 on any non-trivial subject.

replies.author: Kutlu Kanyılmaz
replies.text:
​@David That's very interesting. I tried the "eugenics" search again and checked. Mine only went up to 18. Here's what I did:

I searched for "cotton candy" and it went up to 26. But on page 26, at the bottom of the page, it said that "similar results were omitted", and that I could "repeat the search with omitted results included". I clicked this option, and it went up to 41.

I tried this method with the "eugenics" search, and it went up to 46.

Summary of my experiment: a search for "cotton candy" with the omitted results included goes up to 41; a search for "eugenics" with omitted results included goes up to 46.

There is definitely targeted and (seemingly) ideological suppression in the Google ecosystem, but I don't think it's being done in the way that you describe.

A better interpretation for the truncation of the search result pages is that many people don't even use the second page. Optimization of algorithms is a huge concern for these tech companies.

Thanks for the interesting take, though.

replies.author: David
replies.text: @Kutlu Kanyılmaz I checked. They stop at page 16. That’s 158 results out of a supposed 13.7 million.

replies.author: Kutlu Kanyılmaz
replies.text: What does this mean exactly? I tried searching for "eugenics" and then clicked page 6. It worked without problems.

topLevelComment.author: David
topLevelComment.text:
Step 1: stop using Google. Because it is the most filtered (censored) and biased search engine there is.

When’s the last time you tried clicking past more than 10-20 pages? That’s right — you can’t. They stop.
